titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice, Governance and Civil Society, Office Files of Joseph Schull
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice, Governance and Civil Society, Office Files of Joseph Schull FA1712

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-11-01 04:58:35 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice, Governance and Civil Society, Office Files of Joseph Schull

physdesc.extent: 6 boxes (4 letter document containers and 2 legal document containers)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into one series: Subject Files

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph Schull started at the Ford Foundation in 1991 as an assistant program officer in the International Affairs program. By 1993, he was promoted to deputy director of the International Affairs program. In 1996, Ford Foundation program areas were restructured, and he became deputy director of the Governance and Civil Society program within the Peace and Social Justice division. The Governance and Civil Society program's overarching goals were to improve governmental performance and accountability, find new approaches to implement public policies, and enhance the role of civic organizations in promoting democratic values. Schull worked to fund new initiatives in Russia and Eastern Europe. Schull left the Ford Foundation for Warburg Pincus in 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joseph Schull served as a program officer and deputy director of the International Affairs and the Governance and Civil Society programs at the Ford Foundation between 1991 and 1998. His work focused on creating new foundation initiatives in Russia and Eastern Europe. The collection is comprised of trip reports, articles on civil society issues, Ford program review materials, background papers, policy documents, and conference materials.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2019 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2019:115.
